Professional Hiring Experience is often the first thing that talent acquisition professionals look for when hiring professionals. However, it does not indicate whether the individual will successfully integrate into the team and how likely they are to stay at the organization. And the evidence suggests that the idea that candidates with more experience will perform better and go on to be long-tenured employees is unfounded. The more important takeaway should be – has the candidate learned from their previous experiences? It’s vital that hiring managers evaluate how candidates have dealt with situations in the past. Often one of the reasons that employers look for candidates with experience is that they think previous jobs have helped those people build up knowledge and skills. But we’d recommend focusing on the knowledge, skills and personality traits directly rather than using experience as a proxy for these. We believe that candidates are so much more than their resume. A data-driven approach using objective measurement gives a full picture of the individual and enables you to understand their capability based on their readiness to do the job today, their fit with your organization as well as their future potential for growth and impact. We define readiness as the capability of a candidate relative to day one of a specific job role. It comprises the hard and soft skills, and the knowledge that will allow the individual to be successful against the needs of the job right away. A candidate’s potential refers to their capacity to develop into something further — and it’s an important consideration if succession planning and promotability are important. Fit refers to culture fit, company fit and team fit and its importance increases if you need to tackle turnover, drive higher engagement, or add rigor to the cultural experience of your employees. By measuring all of these three elements in an experienced hire, you’re more likely to select the individuals that will thrive in their role and stay longer at your organization. And that’s in addition to objective measurement also helping you to remove bias from the selection process and making it easier to compare candidates against each other, removing the guesswork from hiring decisions. One of the biggest challenges for HR leaders is the level of change in organizations. Roles are evolving at an unprecedented rate which means that the shelf life of some skills is shrinking as new skill requirements come to the fore. This means that the ability to assess and understand an individual’s reskilling potential has never been more crucial, as the traditional skills that once guaranteed success are no longer sufficient. Even experienced hires need to have the ability to learn and adapt to new technologies in the future. That’s why we’ve built a measure into our professional hiring solution that will give you a comprehensive view of both the individual’s critical skills needed for today and their ability and willingness to pick up new skills for the future. This foresight can be the difference between a workforce that thrives and one that becomes obsolete.
